stem: For each assessment finding, click to specify if the finding is consistent with right-sided heart failure, left-sided heart failure, or neither.

itemContext.sbar: John Smith is a 72-year-old male admitted with shortness of breath and lower extremity edema. He has a history of hypertension and coronary artery disease.

tabs.title: Labs
tabs.content: BNP: 800 pg/mL, Chest X-ray: Cardiomegaly and pulmonary congestion

rationale.correct: Right-sided heart failure leads to systemic fluid retention, causing edema and JVD. Left-sided heart failure leads to pulmonary congestion, causing crackles and shortness of breath.
rationale.incorrect: Incorrect selections indicate a misunderstanding of the pathophysiology of right-sided and left-sided heart failure.
clinicalPearls: Distinguishing between right- and left-sided heart failure is crucial for guiding treatment.
BNP is a marker for heart failure, but other clinical findings are necessary for diagnosis.
rationale.questionTrap: Students may confuse the symptoms of right- and left-sided heart failure, especially if they don't understand the underlying pathophysiology.
rationale.mnemonic: L for Lungs (Left-sided heart failure causes lung issues), R for Rest of the body (Right-sided heart failure causes systemic issues).
